subject: Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... Lexical sets will be quite useable I m sure but the initially proposed application to QS is not workable. We must not attempt to create a universal accent
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
> Here's a rough mapping from the 27 Wells lexical sets

Lexical sets will be quite useable I'm sure but the initially
proposed application to QS is not workable.

We must not attempt to create a universal accent by inferences from
spelling. If your accent merges two sounds, you must use just one QS
letter and not attempt to use the other. Presumably the QS letter to
choose is the one whose RP sound most closely resembles your unified
sound.

Generally, basing QS spelling on TO spellings is a disastrous plan:

- It is an attempt to solve a purely theoretical problem that does not
in fact exist: the variations in phonetic QS spelling do not remotely
result in unreadability even in junior and even less so in senior. If
an Australian spells "accent" with a different initial vowel, it is
just one letter out of 6 in one word out of 50 and is unimportant. I
believe I demonstrated this in comparing samples from two accents and
can do it again at anyone's request.

- It freezes QS spelling so changes in pronunciation will never be
reflected in writing. One is just creating a new TO with letters of a
different shape which is a pointless exercise.

- One has the absurd situation of answering the question "why do I
spell it thus" with "because TO does and TO does it because in 13th
century London the queen had a lisp". Why bother with QS if it mealy
lengths the explanation for ludicrous spelling rather than just
sticking to TO and it's lisping monarch.

- You base QS spelling on TO words that themselves may change. eg
color vs colour

- There are exceptions to any such rules that will cause QS users to
produce exactly the wrong result: if a person merging [I] and [i] is
told to "use #26 for words of that sound that have a TO letter 'i' in
the spelling and use #27 for all others with that sound" then they
will spell "busy" and "bean" with the same letter. in this case "busy"
with [i] something not done in RP or anywhere. But if you reveres the
instructions the problem now exists with "bean"


Still it looks like Lexical set's are quite usable in a solution,
perhaps as follows: map the 27 Wells sets to QS letters for each
accent then summarize the result with an example word from that set (
presumably the set name ). And if I put the lexical sets THOUGHT and
LOT under the QS letter Ox while Kingsley puts THOUGHT under the QS
letter Awe, we will still be able to communicate quite clearly, I promise.
So I suggest that the Lexical set mapping you posted be used only by
RP English speakers and alternative ones must be made for other accents.
